text: Background[edit] Balochistan has been the site of a protracted insurgency since the 1970s, with ethnic Baloch groups accusing the Pakistani government of exploiting the province's natural resources while marginalising local populations.[6] The BLA, designated as a terrorist organisation by Pakistan, the United States, and the European Union, has conducted numerous attacks on security forces and infrastructure projects, including those linked to the China–Pakistan Economic Corridor.[7] Analysts described the 31 January assaults as a retaliatory escalation, marking one of the deadliest days for militants in recent years.[8]  Attacks[edit] The attacks began around 03:00 PKT and spanned at least nine districts, including Quetta, Gwadar, Mastung, Nushki, Pasni, Kharan, and others.[6][9] Militants used guns, grenades, and suicide vests to target police stations, paramilitary outposts, a high-security prison in Quetta, and civilian vehicles.[10] In Quetta, assailants stormed multiple police facilities, leading to prolonged gunbattles.[7] Suicide bombings were reported in Mastung and Nushki, while in Gwadar and Kharan, civilians were among those killed during the clashes.[8] The BLA described the operations as simultaneous strikes on military and administrative targets, with videos released by the group showing female fighters participating.[7] Pakistani officials reported that security forces thwarted most attempts, engaging in clearance operations that lasted into the following day.[9]  Casualties and aftermath[edit] Initial reports varied, but by 1 February, official figures confirmed 15 security personnel and 18 civilians killed, with an unspecified number injured.[6][8] At least 92 militants were killed during the counter-operations, bringing the total death toll to over 120.[10][9]  Reactions[edit] Pakistan's military condemned the attacks as attempts to undermine stability in Balochistan.[9] International responses included statements from Turkey, which expressed condolences and reaffirmed support against terrorism;[11] Qatar, which rejected violence in all forms;[12] and China, which praised Pakistani forces for thwarting the militants.[13]  See also[edit] Insurgency in Balochistan Balochistan Liberation Army List of terrorist incidents in 2026 References[edit]   ^ a b "TRT World - Pakistan forces repel coordinated Balochistan attacks, kill 133 terrorists".
source: 2026 Balochistan attacks - Wikipedia

text: But most of the speculation was that Article 35A of the Indian constitution, which gave some special privileges to the people of the state, would be scrapped.The government then stunned everyone by saying it was revoking nearly all of Article 370, which 35A is part of and which has been the basis of Kashmir's complex relationship with India for some 70 years.

text: In the first few days of August, there were signs of something afoot in Kashmir.Tens of thousands of additional Indian troops were deployed, a major Hindu pilgrimage was cancelled, schools and colleges were shut, tourists were ordered to leave, telephone and internet services were suspended and regional political leaders were placed under house arrest.

text: PTI PhotoAdvertisementThe terrorist attack in Pahalgam in Jammu and Kashmir on Tuesday, that killed 26 tourists, is among the deadliest incidents in the region since it was engulfed by Pakistan-sponsored terrorism in 1991.AdvertisementHere is a timeline of major terrorist attacks that have shaken Kashmir over the past 25 years:Advertisement2000: Terrorists attacked the minority Sikh community in Chattisinghpora village in Anantnag district on March 21, the eve of then US President Bill Clinton’s state visit to India, killing 36 civilians and injuring many more.AdvertisementIn August 2000, terrorists attacked the Nunwan base camp of the Amarnath Yatra, killing 32 persons, including 24 pilgrims.2001: In July, terrorists targeted the Amarnath Yatra pilgrimage after breaching the security cordon at Sheshnag Lake and exploding two Improvised Explosive Devices (IEDs).
source: Timeline of major terrorist attacks in Kashmir over past 25 ...

text: Pakistani security forces responded with counter-operations, resulting in at least 125 deaths,[1] including 15 security personnel, 18 civilians, and at least 92 assailants.[3][4][5] The attacks occurred amid an ongoing insurgency in Balochistan, in which separatist groups are seeking greater autonomy or independence from Pakistan.
source: 2026 Balochistan attacks - Wikipedia

text: The area was once a princely state called Jammu and Kashmir, but it joined India in 1947 soon after the sub-continent was divided up at the end of British rule.India and Pakistan subsequently went to war over it and each came to control different parts of the territory with a ceasefire line agreed.

text: Thirteen individuals died, comprising eight Hindu pilgrims, three Muslim civilians, and two security personnel.These assaults underscored militants’ intent to disrupt religious tourism and stoke communal tension.Srinagar Assembly Bombing, 2001: Assault on DemocracyIn October 2001, attackers rammed a suicide car bomb into the Jammu & Kashmir Legislative Assembly complex in Srinagar.

text: Thirteen people were killed, including eight Hindu pilgrims, three Muslim civilians, and two security personnel.AdvertisementIn October, a suicide car bomb struck the Jammu and Kashmir Legislative Assembly complex in Srinagar, killing 36 people and injuring many others.2002: In May, terrorists entered a lightly guarded Army camp at Kaluchak in Jammu, killing 36 persons—mostly women and children.

text: This attack shocked global audiences by highlighting that no community was safe, sparking condemnation from the Indian government and international media alike.Amarnath Yatra Attacks: Striking Pilgrims in 2000 and 2001The annual Amarnath pilgrimage—drawing thousands of Hindu devotees—emerged as a high-profile target:Nunwan Base Camp Attack (August 2000): Militants opened fire on pilgrims at the Nunwan campsite, killing 32 people, including 24 devotees.
